newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia, Belarus to sign amended union deal-source.
newsitem.headline: Russia, Belarus to sign amended union deal-source.

text.p: Presidents Boris Yeltsin of Russia and Alexander Lukashenko of Belarus will sign a short, 10-point Union Treaty on Wednesday which differs from the original draft, Kremlin sources said.

The sources told Reuters the bulk of the original 17-page draft, with its most controversial part, would form the basis of a charter of the Union, which Yeltsin and Lukashenko would only initial on Wednesday and then send for public debate.
The decision to sign only a short accord appears to reflect a compromise reached in last-minute bargaining.

Lukashenko and the more conservative part of the Russian leadership had wanted a more binding document to be signed, including the detailed section which appears to have been transferred into the charter.

Liberals in the Russian government opposed the original draft, saying they feared union could harm Russia's economy and make Lukashenko, who once professed an admiration for Adolf Hitler, a key player in Moscow politics.

The draft of the "Treaty on a Union of Belarus and Russia", obtained by Reuters on Monday, provided for the two former Soviet republics to coordinate foreign, economic and defence policies but stopped short of a merger into a single state.
On Tuesday, Yeltsin sent his Security Council secretary Ivan Rybkin to Minsk to present some changes to the text.

Lukashenko flew to Moscow on Tuesday night, earlier than scheduled and went into one-to-one talks with Yeltsin in the Kremlin on Wednesday morning to put the finishing touches to the accord. They later opened a formal session of the Russia-Belarus Community, formed last year. The session will be followed by a signing ceremony.
